'''Bradbury''' is a small, affluent city in the [[San Gabriel Valley]] region of [[Los Angeles County, California]], [[United States]]. It is located in the [[foothills of California|foothills]] of the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] below [[Angeles National Forest]]. Bradbury is bordered by the city of [[Monrovia, California|Monrovia]] to the west, and [[Duarte, California|Duarte]] to the south and east. The population was 1,048 at the 2010 census, up from 855 at the 2000 census. The city has three distinct areasâthe Bradbury Estates, which is a gated community consisting of {{convert|5|acre|m2|sing=on}} minimum estates; Woodlyn Lane, which is also a gated community with minimum {{convert|2|acre|m2|sing=on}} lots; and the balance of the city, which is not gated, which has lots generally ranging in size from {{convert|7500|sqft|m2}} to {{convert|1|acre|m2|adj=on}}. A significant portion of the properties in Bradbury Estates and Woodlyn Lane are zoned for horses, and several horse ranches still exist within these communities today.
In September 2010, [[Forbes]] magazine placed Bradbury's zip code of 91008 at #1 on their annual list of America's most expensive zip codes, with a median home price of $4,276,462.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.forbes.com/zipcodes/2010/zipspage.html?zip=91008&city=Duarte | work=Forbes | first=David | last=Ewalt | title=Forbes Luxury Housing Index | date=2010-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.forbes.com/2010/09/27/most-expensive-zip-codes-2010-lifestyle-real-estate-zip-codes-10-zips_land.html | work=Forbes | first=Francesca | last=Levy | title=America's Most Expensive ZIP Codes | date=2010-09-27}}</ref>
==Geography== Bradbury is located at {{Coord|34|8|58|N|117|58|28|W|type:city}} (34.149306, -117.974319).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|2.0|sqmi|km2}}, over 99% of it land.
==Demographics== ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Bradbury had a population of 1,048. The [[population density]] was 535.0 people per square mile (206.6/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Bradbury was 652 (62.2%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 22 (2.1%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 4 (0.4%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 276 (26.3%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0 (0.0%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 59 (5.6%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 35 (3.3%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 218 persons (20.8%).
The Census reported that 1,048 people (100% of the population) lived in households, 0 (0%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 0 (0%) were institutionalized.
There were 354 households, out of which 92 (26.0%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 231 (65.3%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 27 (7.6%) had a female householder with no husband present, 15 (4.2%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 18 (5.1%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 2 (0.6%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 61 households (17.2%) were made up of individuals and 24 (6.8%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.96. There were 273 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (77.1% of all households); the average family size was 3.27.
The population was spread out with 173 people (16.5%) under the age of 18, 84 people (8.0%) aged 18 to 24, 196 people (18.7%) aged 25 to 44, 386 people (36.8%) aged 45 to 64, and 209 people (19.9%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 49.1 years. For every 100 females there were 94.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.0 males.
There were 400 housing units at an average density of 204.2 per square mile (78.8/kmÂ²), of which 307 (86.7%) were owner-occupied, and 47 (13.3%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 1.0%; the rental vacancy rate was 7.8%. 934 people (89.1% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 114 people (10.9%) lived in rental housing units.
===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 855 people, 284 households, and 239 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 447.3 inhabitants per square mile (172.8/kmÂ²). There were 311 housing units at an average density of 162.7 per square mile (62.9/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 70.53% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 1.75% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.23% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 19.53% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 5.61% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2.34% from two or more races. 13.92% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race.
There were 284 households out of which 33.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 69.4% were married couples living together, 8.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 15.5% were non-families. 12.0% of all households were made up of individuals and 3.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.01 and the average family size was 3.21.
In the city the population was spread out with 24.7% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 25.5% from 25 to 44, 28.8% from 45 to 64, and 15.3% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females there were 90.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 95.2 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $100,454, and the median income for a family was $106,736. Males had a median income of $56,250 versus $40,000 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $57,717. None of the families and 2.0% of the population were living below the [[poverty line]], including no under eighteens and none of those over 64.
==Education==
Bradbury and Duarte are both served by the [[Duarte Unified School District]]. However, many of Bradbury's residents prefer to send their children to private schools in the area.
==Politics== In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Bradbury is located in the 29th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Republican [[Bob Huff]], and in the 59th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Republican [[Tim Donnelly (politician)|Tim Donnelly]]. Federally, Bradbury is located in [[California's 26th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of R +4<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Republican [[David Dreier]].
==Public safety== The [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] (LASD) serves Bradbury through the operation of the Duarte satellite substation as well as the Temple Station in Temple City.<ref>"[http://www.lasd.org/stations/for1/temple/index.html Temple Station]." [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]]. Retrieved on January 21, 2010.</ref>
The [[Los Angeles County Fire Department]] provides fire protection services, their services assigned to Station 44 in Duarte with backup paramedic assistance from Stations 29 in Baldwin Park and 32 in Azusa, as well as the Monrovia Fire Department.

Stanley Williams]], nanotechnologist{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}<!-- cite residence -->
